ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Three days of virtual seminar, two days of recorded lectures.
Asynchronous recorded lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about more complex Latin art and culture that made me think much more in-depth than I usually do in a Spanish course. I also strengthened my grammatical skills.
I was able to learn more about and refine my Spanish grammar. I also learned a lot about South American cultures and various other things.
This course helped me develop my fluency, writing and speaking skills in Spanish. It also gave me a lot of insight on the cultures of communities in various Spanish-speaking countries.
I gained a much better understanding of grammar structures and vocabulary in Spanish.
I developed a greater fluency in Spanish in general, but particularly conjugating verb tenses while speaking.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: While I think its good that there was constant engagement with the language, some of the work just felt very tedious and tiring.
I felt that the course had a LOT of assessments, especially towards the end which was a little overwhelming, but overall, it was very engaging and I learned a lot.

The lectures were really helpful in developing fluency, and for the most part, the homework helped me develop my writing. I did, however, find that there was an excessive amount of homework assignments, many of which were tedious at times. I would say fewer assignments, possibly made to be longer, would make this course a lot more manageable.

Strengths: great professor, engaging discussions, clear expectations for hw 

Weaknesses: sometimes felt a bit overwhelming (ex. the 2 weeks with a composition, test, and oral)
I think this class was a great pace and I like the small size.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the in person seminars mixed with the two days of recorded lectures. I wish we were able to see the our tests/quizzes after we turned them in so we could review and improve.

The use of breakout rooms, groups projects, and especially short films made this course really engaging. Still, I felt like we were asked to do a lot of work alone, outside of class, which was sometimes disengaging.
Honestly, the virtual discussions were solid and engaging. I also liked how Tuesdays/Thursdays were reserved for asynchronous learning.
I believe the mix of asynchronous and synchronous helped with zoom fatigue, and I think all zoom features were utilized well, including the chat feature and at times the annotation feature.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it helps a lot with advancing your mastery of the Spanish language.
Yes! Great course to improve/refine your Spanish and you can really see the improvement as the semester goes on.

I would recommend this course to a student looking to complete a language requirement. I would not recommend this course to a student seeking fluency in Spanish. I think that taking an L5 course geared towards reading and speaking (less towards grammar) would be much more suitable for a student with an interest in learning Spanish outside of the language requirement.
Yes, if you are interested in learning Spanish I think L4 is far better than L3.
I would recommend this course to anyone serious about Spanish because I think it helped me a lot, even though the classes were only virtual, which led to some apprehension on my part.
Yes
